Knowledge Point: The definite article di signals definiteness of a noun phrase. It is neutral as to number and can be used with count, mass, and proper nouns alike. Di may precede NPs headed by full nouns (cf. \ref{ex:key:169} below), the numeral wán ‘one’ in its function as a pronominal \REF{ex:key:165}, or any element functioning as a noun, such as the deverbal noun dú in \REF{ex:key:166}\textsc{:}
Content 1: \gll Yu ték \textbf{di} \textbf{maíz} yu hól=an. | \gls 2SG take DEF maize 2SG hold=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘You take the maize and hold it.’
Content 2: \gll Di láyf fɔ́s tɛ́n e bin swít pás \textbf{di} \textbf{wán} tidé. | \gls DEF life first time 3SG.SBJ PST be.sweet pass DEF one today | \glt ‘Life in the past was more enjoyable than that of today.’
Content 3: \gll Mék e bít yú, mék e dú yú \textbf{di} \textbf{dú} e wánt, mék e hála, (...) | \gls SBJV 3SG.SBJ beat 2SG.INDP SBJV 3SG.SBJ do 2SG.INDP DEF do 3SG.SBJ want SBJV 3SG.SBJ shout (...) | \glt ‘Let him beat you, let him do to you what he wants to, let him shout (...)’

Knowledge Point: Proper nouns, such as the place name Camerún ‘Cameroon’ and personal names, do not usually co-occur with the article \REF{ex:key:167}, but may appear with it if required \REF{ex:key:168}:
Content 1: \gll Porque a bin pás na \textbf{Camerún} fɔ́s. | \gls because 1SG.SBJ PST pass LOC PLACE first | \glt ‘Because I passed through Cameroon first.’
Content 2: \gll Na \textbf{di} \textbf{sén} \textbf{Jorge} wé a sabí nɔ́? | \gls FOC DEF same NAME SUB 1SG.SBJ know INTJ | \glt ‘It is the same Jorge that I know, right?’

Knowledge Point: The definite article di is employed in contexts in which a noun is specific, identifiable, and familiar to discourse participants either through its presence in the immediate physical surrounding (e.g. maíz ‘maize’) \REF{ex:key:169}, or through situational inference (e.g. mɔ́nin mɔ́nin tɛ́n ‘early in the morning’) \REF{ex:key:170}:
Content 1: \gll Yu ték \textbf{di} \textbf{maíz} yu hól=an. | \gls 2SG take DEF maize 2SG hold=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘You take the maize and hold it.’
Content 2: \gll \'{A}fta a de mít=an nía di klós dɛn \textbf{di} \textbf{mɔ́nin} \textbf{mɔ́nin} tɛ́n. | \gls then 1SG.SBJ IPFV meet=3SG.OBJ near DEF clothing PL DEF morning REP time | \glt ‘Then I met her near the clothes early in the morning.’

Knowledge Point: The associative use of the article is exemplified in \REF{ex:key:171}. The referent leche ‘milk’ has been established earlier on in discourse. The Spanish noun animal ‘animal’ is therefore definite by association with the antecedent leche:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: The anaphoric use of the article can be seen in the following examples. The referent mán ‘man’ is introduced in \REF{ex:key:172a} by the speaker abbreviated as (hi) (cf. \tabref{tab:1:1.1} in \sectref{sec:1.7}) and taken up as a definite NP by speaker (bo) in (b). Note the presence of the Nigerian Pidgin form haws ‘house’ instead of Pichi hós in (b):\is{anaphora}
Content 1: \gll Dɛn kin fíɛ \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{mán} dán káyn stáyl. | \gls 3PL HAB fear 3PL man that kind style | \glt ‘They (usually) fear their husbands and the like.’

Knowledge Point: Cataphoric use of the article – where the identity of the definite noun is established in following discourse – can be seen in the relative construction in \REF{ex:key:173}:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Singular count nouns are marked for indefiniteness with the cardinal numeral\is{cardinal numerals} wán ‘one’ \REF{ex:key:174}, or with the quantifier sɔn ‘some, a’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:175} below). The numeral wán is not a fully grammaticalised indefinite article. In many contexts, wán retains its lexical meaning of ‘one’. Wán also has pronominal functions and can itself be preceded by the demonstratives dí and dán and the definite article di (e.g. \ref{ex:key:165}).
Content 1: \gll A gɛ́t \textbf{wán} \textbf{bíg} \textbf{sísta} wé na mulata. | \gls 1SG.SBJ get one big sister SUB FOC African-European.F | \glt ‘I have a/one big sister who is African-European.’
Content 2: \gll A wánt mék yu dú mí \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{fébɔ}, mék yu wás mi sɔn klós dɛn. | \gls 1SG.SBJ want SBJV 2SG do 1SG.INDP some favour SBJV 2SG wash 1SG.INDP some clothing PL | \glt ‘I want you to do me a favour (and) wash some clothes for me.’
Content 3: \gll Di láyf fɔ́s tɛ́n e bin swít pás \textbf{di} \textbf{wán} tidé. | \gls DEF life first time 3SG.SBJ PST be.sweet pass DEF one today | \glt ‘Life in the past was more enjoyable than that of today.’

Knowledge Point: When used with count nouns, wán usually signals a higher degree of specificity than sɔn. However, there is no categorical distinction between specific and non-specific deixis in Pichi. This can be seen in the following two sentences. Here the noun fébɔ ‘favour’ appears with sɔn ‘some, a’ in \REF{ex:key:175} and wán ‘one, a’ in a specific and emphatic setting in \REF{ex:key:176}:
Content 1: \gll A wánt mék yu dú mí \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{fébɔ}, mék yu wás mi sɔn klós dɛn. | \gls 1SG.SBJ want SBJV 2SG do 1SG.INDP some favour SBJV 2SG wash 1SG.INDP some clothing PL | \glt ‘I want you to do me a favour (and) wash some clothes for me.’
Content 2: \gll Na sé, na layk sé di mán de mék yú \textbf{wán} \textbf{fébɔ}. | \gls FOC QUOT FOC like QUOT DEF man IPFV make 2SG.INDP one favour | \glt ‘It is that, it is as if the man is doing you a favour.’

Knowledge Point: Given that Pichi does not mark number on nouns morphologically, wán, rather than sɔn, is used to express that singular number is a significant feature of the referent as in wán motó ‘one car’ \REF{ex:key:177}\is{cardinal numerals}. Here an interpretation of wán as a numeral would appear awkward, since the speaker does not have more than one car in mind:
Content 1: \gll Yu sabí sé \textbf{wán} \textbf{motó} fɔ wán mún na cincuenta dólar, ɛf yu hól wán motó fɔ wán mún. | \gls 2SG know QUOT one car PREP one month FOC fifty dollar if 2SG hold one car PREP one month | \glt ‘You know that a car for one month is fifty dollars, if you keep a car for only one month.’

Knowledge Point: Wán rather than sɔn is also common in emphatic contexts. The data does not contain a single sentence in which a noun is preceded by sɔn in an equative clause of the type in \REF{ex:key:178}, in which the identified entity is highly specific. The numeral wán may also signal additional emphasis\is{emphasis} when it precedes a noun under cleft focus\is{cleft constructions} in a presentative construction, as in \REF{ex:key:179} (cf. also \sectref{sec:7.4.4}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Na} \textbf{wán} \textbf{ɔnkúl} \textbf{directo}, fɔ mi mamá in papá in fámbul pát. | \gls FOC one uncle direct PREP 1SG.POSS mother 3SG.POSS father 3SG.POSS family part | \glt ‘(He) is a direct uncle on my mother’s father’s family’s side.’
Content 2: \gll E dé complicado, \textbf{na} \textbf{wán} \textbf{tín} \textbf{dat}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ BE.LOC complicated FOC one thing that | \glt ‘It’s complicated, it’s one (kind of a) thing.’

Knowledge Point: Contrary to what one would expect of a cardinal numeral that signals singular number, wán can also modify a noun containing a numeral above one \REF{ex:key:180}. Such usage of wán is often found in conjunction with Spanish numerals and head nouns and is likely to be a case of structural borrowing\is{borrowing} from Spanish. In Spanish, the plural indefinite article (unos/unas) fulfills an identical function (cf. also \sectref{sec:13.3.1}): \is{article}
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta wi kán mít layk \textbf{wán} \textbf{seis} \textbf{años} después. | \gls then 1PL real meet like one six year.PL afterwards | \glt ‘Then we met again some six years later.’ [fr03ft 191]

Knowledge Point: With plural count nouns, indefiniteness is signalled through the presence of sɔn alone \REF{ex:key:181} or the absence of a definiteness expression altogether (cf. \sectref{sec:5.1.4}). Mass nouns may only be modified by sɔn for indefiniteness, or they occur devoid of any determiner \REF{ex:key:182}:
Content 1: \gll Wi gɛ́t \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{fámbul} dé, na dán yu, na yu prima. | \gls 1PL get some family there FOC that 2SG FOC 2SG cousin.F | \glt ‘We have a family member there, it’s your, it’s your female cousin.’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, wán, but not sɔn, may occur with NPs that are within the scope of negation, even if only with an emphatic meaning \REF{ex:key:183}. In the absence of emphasis, NPs do not usually appear with a marker of indefiniteness in negative clauses \REF{ex:key:184} (cf. \sectref{sec:7.2.2} for details):
Content 1: \gll Sóté a \textbf{nó} tɔ́k \textbf{nó} \textbf{wán} \textbf{wɔ́d}. | \gls until 1SG.SBJ NEG talk NEG one word | \glt ‘Until I didn’t say a single word (anymore).’
Content 2: \gll Yu sabí sé yu \textbf{nó} gɛ́t \textbf{pikín}? | \gls 2SG know QUOT 2SG NEG get child | \glt ‘Do you (really) know that you don’t have a child?’

Knowledge Point: In both \REF{ex:key:185} and \REF{ex:key:186}, wán and sɔn refer to a preceding NP televisión ‘TV set’. When referring to a plural noun, sɔn may optionally be followed by the pluraliser dɛn ‘\textsc{pl}’ \REF{ex:key:187}: \is{anaphora}
Content 1: \gll Yɛ́s, a gɛ́t \textbf{wán}. | \gls yes 1SG.SBJ get one | \glt ‘Yes, I have one [a TV set].’
Content 2: \gll Na só mi yón sɛ́f, a jɔ́s báy \textbf{sɔn}. | \gls FOC like.that 1SG.POSS own EMP 1SG.SBJ just buy some | \glt ‘That’s how it is with me as well, I just bought one [a TV set].’
Content 3: \gll A gɛ́t \textbf{sɔn} \textbf{dɛn}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ get some PL | \glt ‘I have some (PL).’

Knowledge Point: Sɔn and wán may also be used with a partitive\is{partitive} reading when followed by a definite possessed noun. Once more the nominal referent preceded by sɔn tends to receive a less specific reading than the one featuring wán. The same meaning may alternatively be expressed if sɔn or wán are followed by a definite fɔ-prepositional phrase (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:247}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Sɔn} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{di} \textbf{watá} dé yét. | \gls some PREP DEF water BE.LOC yet | \glt ‘Some of the water still remains.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstratives may be used attributively as prenominal modifiers. The forms dí and dís are equivalent in function, although dí is more common as a proximal demonstrative \REF{ex:key:192}:
Content 1: \gll Djunais tɔ́k sé, nɔ́ Rubi \textbf{dí} \textbf{gɛ́l} lɛ́k yú. | \gls NAME talk QUOT INTJ NAME this girl like 2SG.INDP | \glt ‘Djunais said, really Rubi, this girl likes you.’

Knowledge Point: The two forms dá and dán serve as distal attributive demonstratives \REF{ex:key:193}. The form dán is used in the majority of cases, irrespective of the word-initial onset of the following noun. NPs featuring an attributively used demonstrative are pluralised in the usual way by means of the postposed pluraliser\is{pluraliser} dɛn \REF{ex:key:193}:
Content 1: \gll Ɔ́l \textbf{dán} pikín \textbf{dɛn} na dán mán in yón. | \gls all that child PL FOC that man 3SG.POSS own | \glt ‘All those children are that man’s.’ [hi03cb 190]
Content 2: \gll Ɔ́l \textbf{dán} pikín \textbf{dɛn} na dán mán in yón. | \gls all that child PL FOC that man 3SG.POSS own | \glt ‘All those children are that man’s.’ [hi03cb 190]

Knowledge Point: Dí and dís \REF{ex:key:194}, as well as dá and dán (cf. e.g. \ref{ex:key:202}) may combine with the numeral and pronominal wán ‘one’, in order to form singular \REF{ex:key:194} and plural \REF{ex:key:195} demonstrative pronominals:
Content 1: \gll A tínk sé \textbf{dí} \textbf{wán} na wán problema fɔ Afrika, ɛ́n. | \gls 1SG.SBJ think QUOT this one FOC one problem PREP PLACE SP | \glt ‘I think that this is a problem in Africa.’
Content 2: \gll Ɛhɛ́, wán glás watá aparte, yu pút=an ínsay, \textbf{dán} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé,} yu fít ték medio fɔ dán sén glas (...) | \gls INTJ one glass water separate 2SG put=3SG.OBJ inside that one there 2SG can take half PREP that same glass (...) | \glt ‘Exactly, one glass of water separately, you put it inside, as for that one, you can take half in that very glass (...)’
Content 3: \gll A tínk sé \textbf{dí} \textbf{wán} na wán problema fɔ Afrika, ɛ́n. | \gls 1SG.SBJ think QUOT this one FOC one problem PREP PLACE SP | \glt ‘I think that this is a problem in Africa.’
Content 4: \gll Na dé \textbf{dís} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dɛn} mamá dɛn de mék ɛ́ni tín. | \gls FOC there this one 3PL mother 3PL IPFV make every thing | \glt ‘It is then that these ones’ mothers do every thing.’

Knowledge Point: Dís and dát, but never dí and dá/dán, also occur in sentence-final position in a presentative construction of the type presented in \REF{ex:key:198} and \REF{ex:key:199}, where the demonstratives are anaphoric to an antecedent focused NP (cf. \sectref{sec:7.4.4})\textsc{:} \is{anaphora}
Content 1: \gll Sé \textbf{na} ín \textbf{dís}, \textbf{na} yu húman \textbf{dís}, yu wánt ɔ yu nó wánt, \textbf{na} in \textbf{dís}. | \gls QUOT FOC 3SG.INDP this FOC 2SG woman this 2SG want or 2SG NEG want FOC 3SG.POSS this | \glt ‘(She said) this is her, this is your wife, you like it or not, this is her.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Na} in vida \textbf{dát}. | \gls FOC 3SG.POSS  life that | \glt ‘That’s his (kind of) life.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstrative adjectives do not co-occur with the definite article. They may, however, precede proper nouns \REF{ex:key:200} and possessive pronouns \REF{ex:key:201}:\is{article}
Content 1: \gll Lúk=an, di dé wé \textbf{dís} \textbf{Paquita} in papá bin kán ték=an, e pé avioneta. | \gls look=3SG.OBJ DEF day SUB this NAME 3SG.POSS father PST come take=3SG.OBJ 3SG.SBJ pay small.aircraft | \glt ‘Look at this, the day that Paquita’s father came to take her, he hired a small aircraft.’
Content 2: \gll Cuñado, mí gɛ́fɔ fɛ́n \textbf{dán} \textbf{mi} prima ó, Cristina. | \gls brother-in-law 1SG.INDP have.to look.for that 1SG.POSS cousin.F SP NAME | \glt ‘Brother(-in-law), I [EMP] really have to look for that my (female) cousin, Cristina.’

Knowledge Point: Demonstratives are often reinforced through the deictic locative adverbs\is{locative adverbials} yá ‘here’, dé ‘there’, and sometimes yandá ‘yonder, over there’ \REF{ex:key:202}:
Content 1: \gll Ɛhɛ́, wán glás watá aparte, yu pút=an ínsay, \textbf{dán} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé,} yu fít ték medio fɔ dán sén glas (...) | \gls INTJ one glass water separate 2SG put=3SG.OBJ inside that one there 2SG can take half PREP that same glass (...) | \glt ‘Exactly, one glass of water separately, you put it inside, as for that one, you can take half in that very glass (...)’

Knowledge Point: The idiom dís-tín ‘this-thing’ may substitute for an inanimate noun. Example \REF{ex:key:203} shows that this expression has been lexicalised to an extent which allows the occurrence of the demonstrative dán ‘that’ with its full referential meaning:
Content 1: \gll A ték tú peso a báy \textbf{dán} \textbf{dís-tín} (...) | \gls 1SG.SBJ take two peso 1SG.SBJ buy that this-thing (...) | \glt ‘I took two pesos (and) I bought this whatsit (...)’

Knowledge Point: The \textsc{3pl} dependent personal pronoun and pluraliser dɛn occasionally occurs in the determiner position at the very left of the NP. In this position, dɛn simultaneously functions as a plural definite article and a demonstrative with a largely discourse deictic function. Prenominal dɛn usually also has emphatic force. This use of dɛn however is marginal in the corpus. Note the additional presence of dɛn as a pluraliser\is{pluraliser} after the noun fronteras ‘borders’ \REF{ex:key:204}: \is{article}
Content 1: \gll Wet ɔ́l \textbf{dɛn} \textbf{fronteras} \textbf{dɛn} wé dɛn de chénch. | \gls with all those borders PL SUB 3PL IPFV change | \glt ‘With all those borders that are changing.’

Knowledge Point: In their function as markers of spatial deixis, the proximal and distal demonstratives serve to locate referents in physical space with the speaker as the deictic centre \REF{ex:key:205}:
Content 1: \gll Wi de gó dɔ́n, wi de gó lɛ́f=an di sáy \textbf{dán} \textbf{motó} \textbf{dé}. | \gls 1PL IPFV go down 1PL IPFV go leave=3SG.OBJ DEF side that car BE.LOC | \glt ‘We’re going down, we are going to leave it where that car is.’

Knowledge Point: The demonstrative pronouns also serve to express discourse-pragmatic deixis. I reiterate example \REF{ex:key:202} above in \REF{ex:key:206} below in context. In the excerpt, speaker (dj) explains how to cook corn porridge. The interjection ɛhɛ́ ‘exactly’ confirms the interruptive question posed in \REF{ex:key:206a}. The topical dán wán dé in (b) is therefore anaphoric to the process explained just beforehand in the same sentence.
Content 1: \gll Ɛhɛ́, wán glás watá aparte, yu pút=an ínsay, \textbf{dán} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé,} yu fít ték medio fɔ dán sén glas (...) | \gls INTJ one glass water separate 2SG put=3SG.OBJ inside that one there 2SG can take half PREP that same glass (...) | \glt ‘Exactly, one glass of water separately, you put it inside, as for that one, you can take half in that very glass (...)’
Content 2: Not found
Content 3: \gll Wán glás watá? | \gls one glass water | \glt ‘One glass of water?’

Knowledge Point: The anaphoric function of the distal demonstrative pronoun is frequently made use of in order to refer to preceding NPs, phrases, and entire sentences. Dán sén glás ‘that very glass’ represents in \REF{ex:key:202} an additional means of referent tracking via the use of the focus and emphasis\is{emphasis} marker sén ‘same, very’: \is{anaphora}
Content 1: \gll Ɛhɛ́, wán glás watá aparte, yu pút=an ínsay, \textbf{dán} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dé,} yu fít ték medio fɔ dán sén glas (...) | \gls INTJ one glass water separate 2SG put=3SG.OBJ inside that one there 2SG can take half PREP that same glass (...) | \glt ‘Exactly, one glass of water separately, you put it inside, as for that one, you can take half in that very glass (...)’

Knowledge Point: Pichi marks plural number via the postposed pluraliser\is{pluraliser} dɛn which is identical to the \textsc{3pl} dependent pronoun. The pluraliser is clitic-like in one respect: It may not be separated from the noun it refers to by any constituent. Typically, the pluraliser occurs with count nouns \REF{ex:key:207}, but it may also follow collective nouns like pípul ‘people’ \REF{ex:key:208}: \is{cliticisation}
Content 1: \gll Yu nó fít jɔ́s trowé di \textbf{tín} \textbf{dɛn} na strít só. | \gls 2SG NEG can just throw.away DEF thing PL LOC street like.that | \glt ‘You can’t just throw the things into the street like that.’
Content 2: \gll Fɔ \textbf{pípul} \textbf{dɛn}, \textbf{pípul} \textbf{dɛn} kin dé na ród, plɛ́nte. | \gls PREP people PL people PL HAB BE.LOC LOC road plenty | \glt ‘Because of people, people are usually on the road, a lot.’

Knowledge Point: The pluraliser is also encountered with mass nouns denoting liquids such as watá ‘water’ \REF{ex:key:209} or leche ‘milk’ in \REF{ex:key:210}:
Content 1: \gll Fít sifta ín sóté tú tɛ́n mék mék dán smɔ́l smɔ́l \textbf{watá} \textbf{dɛn} nó lɛ́f. | \gls can sieve 3SG.INDP until two time make SBJV that small REP water PL NEG leave | \glt ‘(You) can sieve it up to two times in order not to make that little bit of water remain.’
Content 2: \gll A bin de vɔ́mit dán \textbf{leche} \textbf{dɛn} fɔ́s fɔ́s tɛ́n dɛn. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PST IPFV vomit that milk PL first REP time PL | \glt ‘I was throwing up that milk during the first few times.’

Knowledge Point: NPs featuring a cardinal numeral \is{cardinal numerals}can also optionally be marked for plural number \REF{ex:key:211}, although in the majority of instances, speakers prefer not to use the pluraliser together with a numeral \REF{ex:key:212}:
Content 1: \gll E gɛ́t \textbf{tú} \textbf{pikín} \textbf{dɛn} na Panyá sɛ́f. | \gls 3SG.SBJ get two child PL LOC Spain EMP | \glt ‘She even has two children in Spain.’
Content 2: \gll E bríng \textbf{trí} \textbf{kasára}, e lé dɛ́n pantáp di tébul. | \gls 3SG.SBJ bring three cassava 3SG.SBJ lie 3PL.INDP on DEF table | \glt ‘He brought three cassavas and put them on the table.’

Knowledge Point: Furthermore, the pluraliser may co-occur with quantifiers that indicate plurality of the referent such as ɔ́l ‘all’ \REF{ex:key:213}, and bɔkú ‘many, much’ \REF{ex:key:214}, although the absence of plural marking is equally common \REF{ex:key:215}:
Content 1: \gll Yu wánt báy cuaderno, bolí \textbf{ɔ́l} \textbf{dán} \textbf{tín} \textbf{dɛn} na wet dólar. | \gls 2SG want buy exercise.book pen all that thing PL FOC with dollar | \glt ‘You want to buy an exercise book, pen and all those things, it’s with dollars.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Bɔkú} \textbf{motó} \textbf{dɛn} dé yá só, (...) | \gls much car PL BE.LOC here like.that (...) | \glt ‘(Since) there were many cars around, (...)’
Content 3: \gll Mí, lɛk háw yu de sí mí, a dɔ́n sí \textbf{plɛ́nte} \textbf{tín}. | \gls 1SG.INDP like how 2SG IPFV see 1SG.INDP 1SG.SBJ PRF see plenty thing | \glt ‘As for me, as you see me (now), I’ve seen many things (in life).’

Knowledge Point: The pluraliser is also consistently made use of with inserted Spanish nouns marked with the Spanish plural morpheme \{-s\} \REF{ex:key:216}. The same is true of the few instances in the corpus, in which the nouns bɔ́y ‘boy’ and gál ‘girl’ are marked for plural with the marginal Pichi plural morpheme \{-s\} as in \REF{ex:key:217}:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta dɛ́n na mi \textbf{sobrinos} \textbf{dɛn}. | \gls then 3PL.INDP FOC 1SG.POSS nephew.PL PL | \glt ‘So, they are my nephews.’
Content 2: \gll Ɔ́l Ghána \textbf{bɔ́y-s} \textbf{dɛn}, wé dɛn dé (...) | \gls all Ghana boy-PL PL SUB 3PL BE.LOC (...) | \glt ‘All the Ghanaian guys that were around (...)’

Knowledge Point: Personal names may be pluralised in order to form an associative plural \REF{ex:key:218}. The resulting meaning is ‘X and those associated with her/him habitually or at the time of reference’:
Content 1: \gll A dɔ́n explica \textbf{Boyé} \textbf{dɛn}, sé na só mi de mɛ́mba, ɔ́l tín. | \gls 1SG.SBJ PRF explain NAME PL QUOT FOC like.that 1SG.INDP IPFV remember all thing | \glt ‘I have explained to Boyé and the others that this is how I remember everything.’

Knowledge Point: I repeat sentence \REF{ex:key:195} in \REF{ex:key:220} below. As is generally the case in dislocated possessive constructions, a personal pronoun coreferential with the possessor (dɛn ‘\textsc{3pl}’) links the plural possessor (dís wán dɛn ‘these ones’) and the possessed noun (mamá ‘mother’). I interpret the linker dɛn in these cases as the \textsc{3pl} pronoun rather than the pluraliser, since singular possessors require the use of the corresponding singular possessive pronoun in ‘\textsc{3sg.poss}’ in the same position. Hence the pluraliser remains unexpressed in the construction in order to avoid doubling of the two homophonous forms:
Content 1: \gll Na dé \textbf{dís} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dɛn} mamá dɛn de mék ɛ́ni tín. | \gls FOC there this one 3PL mother 3PL IPFV make every thing | \glt ‘It is then that these ones’ mothers do every thing.’
Content 2: \gll Na dé dís wán dɛn mamá \textbf{dɛn} de mék ɛ́ni tín. | \gls FOC there this one 3PL mother 3PL IPFV make every thing | \glt ‘It is then that these ones’ mothers do every thing.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:221}, we encounter a similar overlap of \textsc{pl} and \textsc{3pl}. Here, dɛn may be interpreted as the pluraliser postposed to the NP or instead, as a resumptive pronoun\is{resumptive pronouns} and the subject of the following verb. In contexts such as these, where a predicate immediately follows a plural-referring \textsc{NP}, the distinction between the pluraliser and a \textsc{3pl} resumptive pronoun is not possible, since doubling of the form is normally avoided. The distributional characteristics of dɛn in these contexts indicate the significant functional overlap of \textsc{NP} and verbal number marking in Pichi:
Content 1: \gll Estudiante fɔ Guinea \textbf{dɛn} de sɔ́fa plɛ́nte. | \gls student PREP PLACE 3PL/PL IPFV suffer plenty | \glt ‘Guinean students were suffering a lot.’

Knowledge Point: Finally, I point out that Pichi has at least two nouns with suppletive plural forms which are occasionally employed instead of the regular plural involving dɛn ‘\textsc{pl’}. The relevant singular-plural pairs are gál-gáls ‘girl-girls’ and bɔ́y-bɔ́ys ‘boy-boys’. However, these forms are not suppletive in the true sense, since they feature the segmentable but only marginally productive plural morpheme \{-s\}, which is only attested with these two nouns. As example \REF{ex:key:217} above shows, these forms may also be followed by the pluraliser dɛn.\is{number!nouns}
Content 1: \gll Ɔ́l Ghána \textbf{bɔ́y-s} \textbf{dɛn}, wé dɛn dé (...) | \gls all Ghana boy-PL PL SUB 3PL BE.LOC (...) | \glt ‘All the Ghanaian guys that were around (...)’

Knowledge Point: However, with count nouns, generic reference can also be established by employing a plural noun without a determiner \REF{ex:key:227}:\is{number!nouns}
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mán} \textbf{dɛn} nó de bísin fɔ mék fám mɔ́. | \gls man PL NEG IPFV be.busy PREP make farm more | \glt ‘People are no more into farming.’

Knowledge Point: Example \REF{ex:key:229} illustrates how generic meaning arises through the interplay of NP marking (the bare NP tidé pikín ‘children of today’), impersonal use of \textsc{2sg}, and the habitual\is{habitual aspect} reading of the potential modality marker go:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Tidé} \textbf{pikín} \textbf{yu} \textbf{go} gɛ́t bɛlɛ́, \textbf{yu} púl=an \textbf{yu} \textbf{go} dáy wet bɛlɛ́. | \gls today child 2SG POT get belly 2SG remove=3SG.OBJ 2SG POT die with belly | \glt ‘As for children of today, they get pregnant, they abort it and die because of the pregnancy.’

Knowledge Point: Bare nouns are also encountered in many idiomatic verb-object collocations involving count nouns such as mék fám ‘to farm’, gɛ́t bɛlɛ́ ‘to be pregnant’, or fála húman ‘to womanise’. Such noun phrases are also characterised by genericity by virtue of their non-specific reference. They equally reflect a general tendency to omit indefiniteness and number marking with non-specific objects{\fff} \REF{ex:key:230}: {\fff}
Content 1: \gll A ralla ín \textbf{wet} \textbf{rallador}. | \gls 1SG.SBJ grate 3SG.INDP with grater | \glt ‘I grated it with a grater.’

Knowledge Point: Head nouns of noun phrases may be modified prenominally by other nouns and by verbs in compounds, by nouns in associative constructions, as well as by quantifiers and property items that have been converted to attributive adjectives. In \REF{ex:key:231}, the nouns mán ‘man’ and húman ‘woman’ are modified by the preposed property item bíg ‘(be) big’.
Content 1: \gll Bɔt wé di mán na \textbf{bíg} mán, di húman sɛ́f na \textbf{bíg} húman, porque ɔ́l tɛ́n na húman dé bɔtɔ́n mán. | \gls but SUB DEF man FOC big man DEF woman EMP FOC big woman because all time FOC woman BE.LOC under man | \glt ‘But when the man is a big man, the woman, too is a big woman, because it is always the woman who is below the man.’

Knowledge Point: An ordinal numeral\is{ordinal numerals} or similar quantifier such as ɔ́da ‘other’ immediately follows the article and precedes other modifiers \REF{ex:key:232}:
Content 1: \gll Yu pút \textbf{ɔ́da} \textbf{nyú} wán ínsay, dán wán sé mék e nó smɛ́l. | \gls 2SG put other new one inside that one QUOT SBJV 3SG.SBJ NEG smell | \glt ‘(Then) you put another one inside, that in order for it not to smell.’

Knowledge Point: Secondly, the following more “basic” semantic types of property items have the highest likelihood of occurring as prenominal modifiers to head nouns: dimension (e.g. bíg ‘(be) big’ in \REF{ex:key:231} and smɔ́l ‘(be) small), age (e.g. ól ‘(be) old’, cf. \ref{ex:key:232}), value (e.g. bád ‘(be) bad’, bɛ́ta ‘(be) very good’, fáyn ‘(be) fine, beautiful’, trú ‘(be) true’, and (s)trɔ́n ‘be strong, profound (cf. \ref{ex:key:233}), colour (e.g. blák ‘(be) black’, wáyt ‘(be) white’, and rɛ́d ‘(be) red’):
Content 1: \gll Bɔt wé di mán na \textbf{bíg} mán, di húman sɛ́f na \textbf{bíg} húman, porque ɔ́l tɛ́n na húman dé bɔtɔ́n mán. | \gls but SUB DEF man FOC big man DEF woman EMP FOC big woman because all time FOC woman BE.LOC under man | \glt ‘But when the man is a big man, the woman, too is a big woman, because it is always the woman who is below the man.’
Content 2: \gll Yu pút \textbf{ɔ́da} \textbf{nyú} wán ínsay, dán wán sé mék e nó smɛ́l. | \gls 2SG put other new one inside that one QUOT SBJV 3SG.SBJ NEG smell | \glt ‘(Then) you put another one inside, that in order for it not to smell.’
Content 3: \gll E gɛ́t wán \textbf{trɔ́n} stáyl fɔ tɔ́k=an. | \gls 3SG.SBJ get one strong style PREP talk=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘There’s a profound way of saying it.’

Knowledge Point: Instead, members of the semantic classes listed above preferably occur in other kinds of modifying structures, such as relative constructions \REF{ex:key:235} and compounds \REF{ex:key:236}\is{compounding}:
Content 1: \gll Na wán \textbf{mán} wé e \textbf{lɔ́s}. | \gls FOC one man SUB 3SG.SBJ lose. | \glt ‘He’s a lost man [a hopeless case].’
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: Nouns may be modified by postposed elements of two types: focus particles (cf. \sectref{sec:7.4.2}), the topic marker\is{topic marker} náw ‘now’, and optionally, by quantifiers like wán ‘alone’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:257}–\ref{ex:key:258}), ɔ́l ‘all’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:260}), and dásɔl ‘only’ (cf. \ref{ex:key:270}).
Content 1: \gll Dɛn tɛ́l=an sé “nóto \textbf{ín} \textbf{wán}”. | \gls 3PL tell=3SG.OBJ QUOT NEG.FOC 3SG.INDP one | \glt ‘They told her “it’s not only her”.’
Content 2: \gll Mi \textbf{brɔ́da} \textbf{ín} \textbf{wán} mɛ́n di pikín. | \gls 1SG.POSS brother 3SG.INDP one raise DEF child | \glt ‘My brother raised the [his] child single-handedly.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Di} \textbf{pikín} \textbf{ɔ́l} sé na mi yón bikɔs a dɔ́n pé mɔní. | \gls DEF child all QUOT FOC 1SG.POSS own because 1SG.SBJ PFV pay money | \glt ‘(...) all the children are mine, because I have paid money [the dowry].’
Content 4: \gll Pero di fíba bin kɛ́r wán dé \textbf{dásɔl}. | \gls but DEF fever PST carry one day only | \glt ‘But the fever lasted only one day.’

Knowledge Point: In the associative construction, two nouns are juxtaposed, whereby the “possessor” (the modifier noun) modifies the “possessed” noun (the modified noun). Firstly, this construction is always employed when the possessor is instantiated in a possessive pronoun. Secondly, associative constructions express various relations of modification, either exclusively or in complementarity with compounds (cf. \sectref{sec:4.4}). One relation of modification that is always expressed as an associative construction if the possessor is not a multi-constituent NP is a “measure/entity” relation \REF{ex:key:237}. In such constructions, the modifier noun is the measure (glás ‘glass’) and the modified noun the entity measured (watá ‘water’): \is{associative constructions}
Content 1: \gll Wán \textbf{glás} \textbf{watá}. | \gls one glass water | \glt ‘One glass of water’

Knowledge Point: The dislocated possessive construction requires coreferentiality of the possessive pronoun and the possessor. Hence \REF{ex:key:240}, which involves a \textsc{2sg} person possessor, is ungrammatical:
Content 1: Not found

Knowledge Point: Recursive possessive relations can be expressed by the juxtaposition of possessive constructions, as in \REF{ex:key:241}:
Content 1: \gll Na dé a kán sabí \textbf{mi} mamá \textbf{in} papá \textbf{in} fámbul. | \gls FOC there 1SG.SBJ PFV know 1SG.POSS mother 3SG.POSS father 3SG.POSS family | \glt ‘It is there that I got to know my mother’s father’s family.’

Knowledge Point: In the fɔ-prepositional construction, the possessed noun is followed by a prepositional phrase that contains a full noun functioning as a possessor \REF{ex:key:242} or modifier \REF{ex:key:243}:
Content 1: \gll \'{A}fta Miguel Ángel wé na di lás pikín \textbf{fɔ} mi antí. | \gls then NAME NAME SUB FOC DEF last child PREP 1SG.POSS aunt | \glt ‘Then (there is) Miguel Ángel who is the last child of my aunt.’
Content 2: \gll \'{A}fta dɛn de gɛ́t fisionomía \textbf{fɔ} Afrika dɛn. | \gls then 3PL IPFV get physiognomy PREP PLACE PL | \glt ‘Then, they have African physiognomies.’

Knowledge Point: Unlike the dislocated possessive construction, the “possessor” in the fɔ-construction may be inanimate. This construction therefore typically expresses a relation of modification between a modified (“possessed”) and a modifier (“possessor”) entity. The construction may express various semantic roles including source\index{} \REF{ex:key:244} and material\index{} \REF{ex:key:245} (cf. \sectref{sec:9.1.3} for a complete description of the semantic roles covered by fɔ ‘\textsc{prep’}):
Content 1: \gll Yu nó go gɛ́t hambɔ́g \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{pípul} dɛn. | \gls 2SG NEG POT get irritation PREP people PL | \glt ‘You won’t get any irritation from people.’
Content 2: \gll Dán casa verde, dán casa \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{madera} (...) | \gls that house green that house PREP wood (...) | \glt ‘That green house, that wooden house (...)’

Knowledge Point: The fɔ-construction is also used to express part-whole relations in the idiomatic expression pát fɔ ‘part of’ \REF{ex:key:246} or in a partitive\is{partitive} construction involving the determiner sɔn ‘some’ \REF{ex:key:247}:
Content 1: \gll Gɔ́bna de gí yu \textbf{pát} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{di} \textbf{mɔní}. | \gls government IPFV give 2SG part PREP DEF money | \glt ‘Government gives you part of the money.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Sɔn} \textbf{fɔ} \textbf{di} \textbf{watá} dé yét. | \gls some PREP DEF water BE.LOC yet | \glt ‘Some of the water still remains.’

Knowledge Point: In the corpus, no numeral higher than seven was used in natural speech and no speaker except one could list numerals higher than ‘ten’ without fault. The \ili{Spanish} numeral system is employed by all speakers and has largely replaced Pichi cardinal numerals above three (cf. \sectref{sec:13.3.1} for additional details). Cardinal numerals occur in the prenominal modifier position \REF{ex:key:250} and may be used independently as pronominals \REF{ex:key:251}. The repetition of cardinal numerals renders a distributive sense \REF{ex:key:252}:
Content 1: \gll So a dɔ́n gɛ́t \textbf{trí} \textbf{nacionalidad} na dís wɔ́l. | \gls so 1SG.SBJ PRF get three nationality LOC this world | \glt ‘So I have three nationalities in this world.’
Content 2: \gll Ɛf yu de ték \textbf{trí}, treinta mil. | \gls if 2SG IPFV take three thirty thousand | \glt ‘If you take three, (it is) thirty thousand.’
Content 3: \gll Yu fít kɛ́r dɛ́n \textbf{tú} \textbf{tú}. | \gls 2SG  can  carry 3PL.INDP  two REP | \glt ‘You can carry them two by two.’

Knowledge Point: Pichi has the three lexical ordinal numerals fɔ́s ‘first’ \REF{ex:key:253}, sɛkɔ́n/sɛ́kɔn ‘second’ \REF{ex:key:254}, and lás ‘last’ \REF{ex:key:255}. The first two occur as attributive prenominal modifiers like other property items, while lás ‘last’ preferably occurs in quantifier compounds {\fff}:
Content 1: \gll Na di \textbf{fɔ́s} tín (...) | \gls FOC DEF first thing (...) | \glt ‘It’s the first thing (...)’
Content 2: \gll E gó blánt wet di \textbf{sɛkɔ́n} papá. | \gls 3SG.SBJ go reside with DEF second father | \glt ‘She went to stay with the second father [stepfather].’
Content 3: \gll Mí na di \textbf{las-mán}. | \gls 1SG.INDP FOC DEF last.CPD-man | \glt ‘I’m the last person (here).’

Knowledge Point: Ordinal numerals except ‘first’ may also be formed productively through the use of quantifier compounds involving the modifier noun nɔ́mba ‘number’ and a cardinal numeral as the head. Most people also use this construction to express ‘second’ \REF{ex:key:256}:
Content 1: \gll Di \textbf{nɔmba}-\textbf{tú} pikín, e kán tɛ́l mí di sén tín. | \gls DEF number.CPD-two child 3SG.SBJ PFV tell 1SG.INDP DEF same thing | \glt ‘(As for) the second child, she told me the same thing.’ [ed03sb 027]\is{ordinal numerals}

Knowledge Point: The numeral wán has a number of functions that are derived from its cardinality sense. We have seen that it functions as an indefinite deteminer and a pronominal or nominal substitute (cf. \ref{ex:key:194}–\ref{ex:key:195}). The adverbialising suffix -wán ‘adv’ is also etymologically related to the cardinal numeral wán (cf. also \sectref{sec:5.2.1} and \sectref{sec:5.4.4}). The numeral wán also expresses adverbial meanings such as ‘alone, single-handedly’ with an emphatic{\fff} nuance, as in \REF{ex:key:257}. When used in this way, wán may modify a head noun post-nominally like a postnominal modifier, such as the focus particle sɛ́f ‘self, emp’. However, wán does not modify full nouns by itself. It rather appears after an independent (emphatic) personal pronoun that is coreferential with the full noun in question \REF{ex:key:258} (cf. also \ref{ex:key:289}–\ref{ex:key:290}):
Content 1: \gll A tínk sé \textbf{dí} \textbf{wán} na wán problema fɔ Afrika, ɛ́n. | \gls 1SG.SBJ think QUOT this one FOC one problem PREP PLACE SP | \glt ‘I think that this is a problem in Africa.’
Content 2: \gll Na dé \textbf{dís} \textbf{wán} \textbf{dɛn} mamá dɛn de mék ɛ́ni tín. | \gls FOC there this one 3PL mother 3PL IPFV make every thing | \glt ‘It is then that these ones’ mothers do every thing.’
Content 3: \gll Dɛn tɛ́l=an sé “nóto \textbf{ín} \textbf{wán}”. | \gls 3PL tell=3SG.OBJ QUOT NEG.FOC 3SG.INDP one | \glt ‘They told her “it’s not only her”.’
Content 4: \gll Mi \textbf{brɔ́da} \textbf{ín} \textbf{wán} mɛ́n di pikín. | \gls 1SG.POSS brother 3SG.INDP one raise DEF child | \glt ‘My brother raised the [his] child single-handedly.’
Content 5: \gll Ɛf yu bin dé \textbf{yú} \textbf{wán} yu nó bin fɔ tɔ́k só. | \gls if 2SG PST BE.LOC 2SG.INDP one 2SG NEG PST COND talk like.that | \glt ‘If you had been alone, you wouldn’t have talked like that.’
Content 6: \gll Na \textbf{dɛ́n} \textbf{wán} de disfruta ó. | \gls FOC 3PL one IPFV enjoy SP | \glt ‘It is them alone who are enjoying [it].’

Knowledge Point: The quantifier ɔ́l ‘all’ occurs with count and mass nouns alike. ɔ́l is encountered in a pre- \REF{ex:key:259}, and postnominal position \REF{ex:key:260}, yet without any effect on its quantificational properties:
Content 1: \gll (...) yu de bák \textbf{ɔ́l} \textbf{di} \textbf{mɔní} (...) | \gls (...) 2SG IPFV give.back all DEF money (...) | \glt ‘(...) you return all the money (...)’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Di} \textbf{pikín} \textbf{ɔ́l} sé na mi yón bikɔs a dɔ́n pé mɔní. | \gls DEF child all QUOT FOC 1SG.POSS own because 1SG.SBJ PFV pay money | \glt ‘(...) all the children are mine, because I have paid money [the dowry].’

Knowledge Point: The occurrence of plural marking in the quantifier phrase in \REF{ex:key:263} also illustrates that a distinction between the meanings of ‘everybody’ and ‘all persons/people’ is irrelevant in Pichi, since genericity can be expressed through bare “singular” nouns and plural-marked nouns alike (cf. \sectref{sec:5.1.4}):
Content 1: \gll Mí sɛ́f, \textbf{ɔ́l} \textbf{pɔ́sin} dɛn kin áks mí sé yu dɔ́n bɔ́n? | \gls 1SG.INDP EMP all person PL HAB ask 1SG.INDP QUOT 2SG PFV give.birth | \glt ‘As for me, all people ask me, “do you have a child?”’

Knowledge Point: Ɔ́l ‘all’ may quantify over temporal \REF{ex:key:264} and locative \REF{ex:key:265} expressions. This function may also be fulfilled by the attributive quantifier hól ‘whole’ \REF{ex:key:266}. In general, the use of hól is, however, rare:
Content 1: \gll “\textbf{Ɔ́l} \textbf{tidé} e bin de kɔ́l mí”, e kɔ́l mí wán tɛ́n dásɔl. | \gls all today 3SG.SBJ PST IPFV call 1SG.INDP 3SG.SBJ call 1SG.INDP one time only | \glt ‘“All of today he was calling me [so he says]”, he [actually] called me only once.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Ɔ́l} \textbf{hía} pák polvo. | \gls all here pack dust | \glt ‘All this place is full of dust.’
Content 3: \gll (...) adɔnkɛ́ e nó sí yú wán \textbf{hól} \textbf{dé}, (...) | \gls (...) even.if 3SG.SBJ NEG see 2SG.INDP one whole day (...) | \glt ‘(...) even if she didn’t see you for a whole day, (...)’

Knowledge Point: The quantifiers ónli ‘only’ and sósó ‘only, abundant’ have a distribution similar to hól above and may appear as prenominal, attributive modifiers to the noun. However, contrary to hól, both ónli and sósó may additionally function as quantifying adverbs. Compare the attributive (a) and adverbial (b) uses of ónli \REF{ex:key:267} and sósó \REF{ex:key:268} in the following two sentence pairs\textstyleannotationreference{:}
Content 1: Not found
Content 2: Not found

Knowledge Point: In contrast, the relational quantifier dásɔl ‘only’ behaves like the universal relational quantifier ɔ́l ‘all’. Hence, dásɔl may appear to the very left of the reference noun \REF{ex:key:269} or occur after the reference noun \REF{ex:key:270}. Aside from that, dásɔl is used as a sentence adverb and clause linker (cf. \sectref{sec:10.7.9}):
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dásɔl} \textbf{wán} \textbf{smɔ́l}, wán glas, yu fúlɔp=an. | \gls only one small one glass 2SG fill=3SG.OBJ | \glt ‘Only one small, one glass, you fill it up.’
Content 2: \gll Pero di fíba bin kɛ́r wán dé \textbf{dásɔl}. | \gls but DEF fever PST carry one day only | \glt ‘But the fever lasted only one day.’

Knowledge Point: The quantifier ɛ́ni ‘every’ quantifies over sets. It therefore has a distributive meaning and can only occur with singular count nouns \REF{ex:key:271}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ɛ́ni} \textbf{dé} dɛn de chɔ́p rɛ́s, \textbf{ɛ́ni} \textbf{dé}. | \gls every day 3PL IPFV eat rice every day | \glt ‘Every day they eat rice, every day.’

Knowledge Point: The relative or partitive{\fff} quantifiers sɔn ‘some’, bɔkú ‘much’, plɛ́nte ‘plenty’, and smɔ́l ‘few, a bit’ may quantify over count and mass nouns alike. NPs featuring one of these forms may be compared to an implicit standard of comparison, like smɔ́l ‘few, a bit’ in \REF{ex:key:273} and sɔn ‘some’ in \REF{ex:key:274}:
Content 1: \gll A kin wánt kɔ́f dɛn de trowé \textbf{smɔ́l} \textbf{mélk}, leche tibia na mi trót. | \gls 1SG.SBJ HAB want cough 3PL IPFV pour small milk milk lukewarm LOC 1SG.POSS throat | \glt ‘I would have to cough (and) they would throw away a little bit of milk, lukewarm milk inside my throat.’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Sɔn} \textbf{fés} dɛn dé wé a sabí nɔ́. | \gls some face PL BE.LOC SUB 1SG.SBJ know INTJ | \glt ‘There are some faces that I know, right.’

Knowledge Point: When the standard of comparison is explicit, the quantifier participates in a partitive\is{partitive} construction. Compare bɔkú ‘much, many’ in \REF{ex:key:275} which precedes the standard mi kɔntri-mán dɛn ‘my countrymen’:
Content 1: \gll Bikɔs a gɛ́t \textbf{bɔkú} \textbf{mi} \textbf{kɔntri}-\textbf{mán} dɛn wé dɛn húman kin dé fɔ Annobón. | \gls because 1SG.SBJ get much 1SG.POSS country.CPD-man PL SUB 3PL woman HAB BE.LOC PREP PLACE | \glt ‘Because I have many of my countrymen whose wives are (usually) in Annobón.’

Knowledge Point: Some of the quantifiers covered can function as pronominals, as exemplified with ɔ́l ‘all’ in \REF{ex:key:277} (cf. \tabref{tab:key:5.5} for a complete overview). However, a quantifier phrase featuring a generic noun (e.g. ɔ́l tín ‘all thing’ = ‘everything’) is usually preferred:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Ɔ́l} \textbf{di} \textbf{tín} wé yú an dán mán bin gɛ́t, ɔ́l de lɛ́f fɔ dán mán. | \gls all DEF thing SUB 2SG.INDP and that man PST get all IPFV remain PREP that man | \glt ‘All the things that you and that man had, all remains for that man.’

Knowledge Point: Dependent subject pronouns always occur in finite clauses together with verbs. They may only be separated from the verb by TMA markers, the negator, and preverbal adverbs. Only independent\is{independent pronouns} personal pronouns \is{emphatic pronouns}may be focused \REF{ex:key:278}, topicalised, modified by postposed elements, and conjoined by the coordinators an ‘and’ or ɔ ‘or’ \REF{ex:key:279}:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mí} gɛ́t tú brɔ́da. | \gls 1SG.INDP get two brother | \glt ‘I [EMP] have two brothers.’
Content 2: \gll Bɔt di gɛ́l nó kán grí mék e gí in bɔ́y frɛ́n ɔ di pikín \textbf{ɔ} \textbf{ín} sénwe, e kán rɔ́n. | \gls but DEF girl NEG PFV agree SBJV 3SG.SBJ give 3SG.POSS boy friend or DEF child or 3SG.INDP self 3SG.SBJ PFV run | \glt ‘But the girl didn’t agree to surrender her boyfriend or the child or herself (and) she ran (away).’

Knowledge Point: A focused or topicalised independent pronoun may be followed by a resumptive dependent pronoun \REF{ex:key:280}. This alternative is not very common in the data:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Mí} \textbf{a} nó gɛ́t. | \gls 1SG.INDP 1SG.SBJ NEG get | \glt ‘AS for me, I don’t have (one).’

Knowledge Point: Likewise, only independent personal pronouns occur under focus in cleft constructions {\fff}involving the focus markers na ‘\textsc{foc}’ \REF{ex:key:281}, and nóto ‘\textsc{neg.foc}’. The example also shows the use of independent pronouns (i.e. dɛ́n ‘\textsc{3pl.indp}’) as regular object pronouns (save the clitic =an for \textsc{3sg.obj}):
Content 1: \gll E wás dí klós dɛn, e dráy dɛ́n, nɔ́ \textbf{na} \textbf{mí} dráy dɛ́n. | \gls 3SG.SBJ wash this clothing PL 3SG.SBJ dry 3PL.INDP INTJ FOC 1SG.INDP dry 3PL.INDP | \glt ‘She washed the clothes, she dried them, no, it is me (who) dried them.’

Knowledge Point: The independent form is also selected when a personal pronoun heads a relative clause\is{relative clauses} \REF{ex:key:282} or is employed as a vocative\is{vocatives} \REF{ex:key:283}:
Content 1: \gll Lɛk náw só, \textbf{mí} [\textbf{wé} a nó máred, ɛf a bɔ́n pikín]? | \gls like now like.that 1SG.INDP SUB 1SG.SBJ NEG marry if 1SG.SBJ give.birth child | \glt ‘Like right now, me who is not married, if I had a child?’
Content 2: \gll \textbf{Yú}, kán yá! | \gls 2SG.INDP come here | \glt ‘(Hey) you, come here!’

Knowledge Point: \tabref{tab:key:5.6} above shows that suppletion and grammatical tone are employed for case and number marking. The following two sentences exemplify the use of tone for pronominal inflection. Sentence \REF{ex:key:284} is a double-object construction. The object and emphatic pronoun mí is high-toned. Hence mí must be interpreted as the maleficiary\is{maleficiary} object of the verb tíf ‘steal’, while ordenador ‘computer’ functions as the patient\is{patient} object:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn tíf \textbf{mí} ordenador. | \gls 3PL steal 1SG.INDP computer | \glt ‘They stole a computer from me.’

Knowledge Point: Conversely, \REF{ex:key:285} is a single object construction. The low-toned ponoun mi is a possessive pronoun to the noun ordenador ‘computer’ which functions as a patient NP to the verb tíf ‘steal’:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn tíf \textbf{mi} ordenador. | \gls 3PL steal 1SG.POSS computer | \glt ‘They stole my computer.’

Knowledge Point: The form =an ‘\textsc{3sg.obj}’ is exclusively employed to express object case. It functions as a pronominal object to verbs, prepositions, and locative nouns\is{locative nouns}. It is a clitic that forms a single phonological word with the immediately preceding verb, preposition or locative noun\is{cliticisation}. The pronoun =an is sometimes employed indiscriminately for singular or plural reference. In such cases, it may be considered to function as a kind of transitivity or verbal agreement marker. In \REF{ex:key:286}, =an is coreferential with the plural-referring pronominal ɔ́l:
Content 1: \gll Mí sénwe a mɛ́n=\textbf{an} \textbf{ɔ́l}. | \gls 1SG.INDP EMP 1SG.SBJ care.for=3SG.OBJ all | \glt ‘I [EMP] myself brought them [the children] all up.’

Knowledge Point: Dependent possessive pronouns\is{possessive pronouns} appear before the noun and may in turn be preceded by a demonstrative\is{demonstratives} \REF{ex:key:287}:
Content 1: \gll Pero \textbf{dís} \textbf{una} baf-rúm. | \gls but this 2PL bath.CPD-room | \glt ‘But this your [PL] bathroom [look how dirty it is].’

Knowledge Point: Independent possessive pronouns\is{independent possessive pronouns} are formed by placing a possessive pronoun to the left of the pronominal\is{possessive pronominal} yón ‘own’ \REF{ex:key:288}:
Content 1: \gll E sé a gó mɛ́n pikín dásɔl ɛf a dɔ́n sí \textbf{yu} \textbf{yón}. | \gls 3SG.SBJ QUOT 1SG.SBJ go care.for child only if 1SG.SBJ PRF see 2SG own | \glt ‘She said I will only care for a child when I have seen yours.’

Knowledge Point: In \REF{ex:key:289}, the pronoun yú ‘\textsc{2sg.indp}’ is modified by wán ‘one, alone’. Wán is semantically compatible with plural referents \REF{ex:key:290}. In \REF{ex:key:291}, the pronoun ín ‘\textsc{3sg.indp}’ is modified by dásɔl ‘only’. Note the obligatory use of independent (emphatic) pronouns \is{emphatic pronouns}with these quantifiers:
Content 1: \gll Ɛf yu bin dé \textbf{yú} \textbf{wán} yu nó bin fɔ tɔ́k só. | \gls if 2SG PST BE.LOC 2SG.INDP one 2SG NEG PST COND talk like.that | \glt ‘If you had been alone, you wouldn’t have talked like that.’
Content 2: \gll Na \textbf{dɛ́n} \textbf{wán} de disfruta ó. | \gls FOC 3PL one IPFV enjoy SP | \glt ‘It is them alone who are enjoying [it].’
Content 3: \gll Na \textbf{ín} \textbf{dásɔl} dán húman dɔ́n de wók fɔ. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP only that woman PRF IPFV work PREP | \glt ‘It is only that that that woman is working for.’

Knowledge Point: Sentence \REF{ex:key:292} provides an example of modification by a noun. The country name Camerún ‘Cameroon’ modifies the personal pronoun una ‘\textsc{2pl}’ by apposition. The modifier noun does not take the pluraliser\is{pluraliser} dɛn ‘\textsc{pl}’:
Content 1: \gll A sé bikɔs \textbf{una} \textbf{Camerún} una gɛ́t (...) | \gls 1SG.SBJ QUOT because 2PL PLACE 2PL get (...) | \glt ‘I said because you Cameroonians, you have (...)’

Knowledge Point: Compound pronouns feature a personal pronoun and the quantifiers\is{quantifiers} tú ‘two’ and/or ɔ́l ‘all’. They are formed by the same means as other compounds: The lexical H tone of the initial component(s) is erased and replaced by an L tone while the final component retains its lexically assigned H tone. Evidence that compounding is indeed at work in the formation of compound pronouns comes from (\ref{ex:key:289}–\ref{ex:key:291}) above. The presence of the postposed quantifiers wán ‘alone’ and dásɔl ‘only’ in these examples requires the use of H-toned emphatic personal pronouns. In contrast, the \textsc{3pl} form of the personal pronoun in \REF{ex:key:293} below is L-toned, although the quantifier ɔ́l ‘all’ is in the same syntactic position as wán and dásɔl in (\ref{ex:key:289}–\ref{ex:key:291}) above.\is{number!pronouns}
Content 1: \gll Ɛf yu bin dé \textbf{yú} \textbf{wán} yu nó bin fɔ tɔ́k só. | \gls if 2SG PST BE.LOC 2SG.INDP one 2SG NEG PST COND talk like.that | \glt ‘If you had been alone, you wouldn’t have talked like that.’
Content 2: \gll Na \textbf{ín} \textbf{dásɔl} dán húman dɔ́n de wók fɔ. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP only that woman PRF IPFV work PREP | \glt ‘It is only that that that woman is working for.’
Content 3: \gll \textbf{Dɛn-ɔ́l} \textbf{dɛn} de salút dɛn sɛ́f. | \gls 3PL.INDP.CPD-all 3PL IPFV greet 3PL self | \glt ‘They are all greeting each other.’
Content 4: \gll Ɛf yu bin dé \textbf{yú} \textbf{wán} yu nó bin fɔ tɔ́k só. | \gls if 2SG PST BE.LOC 2SG.INDP one 2SG NEG PST COND talk like.that | \glt ‘If you had been alone, you wouldn’t have talked like that.’
Content 5: \gll Na \textbf{ín} \textbf{dásɔl} dán húman dɔ́n de wók fɔ. | \gls FOC 3SG.INDP only that woman PRF IPFV work PREP | \glt ‘It is only that that that woman is working for.’

Knowledge Point: The collocation dɛn-ɔ́l ‘\textsc{pl}-all’ may be employed in order to signal inclusivity of all referents. The use of a resumptive simplex dependent pronoun as in \REF{ex:key:293} is optional but very common:
Content 1: \gll \textbf{Dɛn-ɔ́l} \textbf{dɛn} de salút dɛn sɛ́f. | \gls 3PL.INDP.CPD-all 3PL IPFV greet 3PL self | \glt ‘They are all greeting each other.’

Knowledge Point: A compound pronoun may also feature the numeral tú ‘two’ as the second component and thereby express dual number \REF{ex:key:294}. Such dual compound pronouns are most frequently formed by additionally incorporating the quantifie\is{quantifiers}r ɔ́l ‘all’ into the compound \REF{ex:key:295}. The data contains no trial compound pronouns formed with the numeral trí ‘three’:
Content 1: \gll Dɛn go reúne, \textbf{dɛn-tú} \textbf{dɛn} go kɔ́l di bɔ́y (...) | \gls 3PL POT meet 3PL.INDP.CPD-two 3PL POT call DEF boy (...) | \glt ‘They would meet, the two of them would call the boy (...)’
Content 2: \gll Yu sí, \textbf{dɛn}-\textbf{ɔl}-\textbf{tú} júmp fɔ bɔ́t di bɔ́l. | \gls 2SG see 3PL.INDP.CPD-all.CPD-two jump PREP head DEF ball | \glt ‘You see, they both jumped to head the ball.’

Knowledge Point: Compound personal pronouns are employed in a regular and conventionalised way in order to express dual number with any of the three plural personal pronouns. Note the deletion of the H tones and replacement by L tones over all components of the dual object wi-ɔl-tú ‘the two of us’ save the last one (i.e. tú ‘two’, which bears its original lexical H tone) in \REF{ex:key:296}:
Content 1: \gll Lɛk sé dɛn de hía \textbf{wi-ɔl-tú} \textbf{wi} de tɔ́k yét. | \gls like QUOT 3PL IPFV hear 1PL.INDP.CPD-all.CPD-two 1PL IPFV talk yet | \glt ‘Like if they heard both of us still talking.’

Knowledge Point: Examples \REF{ex:key:294} and \REF{ex:key:296} also show that dual pronouns are anaphorically referred to (i.e. through the resumptive pronoun\is{resumptive pronouns}s dɛn ‘\textsc{3pl}’ and wi ‘\textsc{1pl}’, respectively) by making use of the corresponding plural pronoun. \is{anaphora}
Content 1: \gll Dɛn go reúne, \textbf{dɛn-tú} \textbf{dɛn} go kɔ́l di bɔ́y (...) | \gls 3PL POT meet 3PL.INDP.CPD-two 3PL POT call DEF boy (...) | \glt ‘They would meet, the two of them would call the boy (...)’
Content 2: \gll Lɛk sé dɛn de hía \textbf{wi-ɔl-tú} \textbf{wi} de tɔ́k yét. | \gls like QUOT 3PL IPFV hear 1PL.INDP.CPD-all.CPD-two 1PL IPFV talk yet | \glt ‘Like if they heard both of us still talking.’

Knowledge Point: The form which is most commonly employed for signalling coordination between two noun phrases is the comitative preposition wet ‘with’ \REF{ex:key:297}. The form an ‘and’ is also used to coordinate noun phrases \REF{ex:key:298} next to being employed as a sentential coordinator (cf. \sectref{sec:10.3}). However, most speakers have a clear preference for wet rather than an:
Content 1: \gll Lydia \textbf{wet} Junior, na dɛ́n a sabí. | \gls NAME with NAME FOC 3PL.INDP 1SG.SBJ know | \glt ‘Lydia and Junior, it’s them I know.’
Content 2: \gll Ɔ́l di tín wé yú \textbf{an} dán mán bin gɛ́t (...) | \gls all DEF thing SUB 2SG.INDP and that man PST get (...) | \glt ‘All the things that you and that man had (...)’
